dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER JAMES LAVELLE, fifties, is idly reading Moby Dick. Dressed in an old-fashioned black soutane. He hears someone enter the confessional. Marks his page. Waits -- MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I first tasted semen when I was seven years old. HOLD CLOSE on LAVELLE. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Nothing to say?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s certainly a startling opening line. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) What is that, irony?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, let’s start again. Are you...What do you...What do you want to say to me? I’m here to listen to whatever you have to say. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I was raped by a priest when I was seven years old. Orally and anally, as they say in the court reports. This went on for five years. Every other day for five years. I bled a lot, as you can imagine. I bled a terrible amount.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Have you spoken to anyone about-- MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I'm speaking to you now.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I mean, have you sought professional help? MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Why, so I could learn how to cope? So I could learn how to live with it? Maybe I don’t want to cope. Maybe T don’t want to learn how to live with it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you make a formal complaint? You can testify-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) The man’s dead. There is silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what to say to you. I have no answer for you, I’m sorry. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) What good would it do anyway, if he were still alive? What'd be the point in killing the bastard? That’d be no news. There’s no point in killing a bad priest. But killing a good one? That'd be a shock, now. They wouldn't know what to make of that. (pause) I’m going to kill you, Father. I’m going to kill you ‘cause you've done nothing wrong. I’m going to kill you ‘cause you're innocent. (pause) Not right now, though. I’11 give you enough time to put your house in order. Make your peace with God. Sunday week, let’s say. I’11 meet you down on the beach there. Down by the water there. (with a laugh) Killing a priest on a Sunday. That’1l be a good one. (pause) Do you not have anything to say to me, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not right now, no. But I’m sure 1/11 think of something. By Sunday week. There is a pause. Then the MAN laughs. The confessional door is heard opening and closing. LAVELLE waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE emerges from the confessional. Looks around -- The church is empty. He stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sepia, b/w, colour photographs, from the ‘20s to the ‘90s of children with priests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and his altar boy, MICHEAL 0’SULLIVAN, serving Communion to his PARISHIONERS. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of whom -- MILO HERLIHY, GERALD RYAN, SIMON ASAMOAH, JACK BRENNAN and VERONICA BRENNAN -- we will encounter in due course.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Body of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Amen. She receives the Eucharist. She is wearing shades to cove a black eye. LAVELLE moves on to the next PARISHIONER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town’s main street. Houses brightly-painted as in a Jacques Demy film. A GRUMPY BASTARD zips by in a wheelchair. A young priest dressed in a black clerical suit -- FATHER TIMOTHY LEARY -- exits the village store with the Sunday newspapers. EXT. OPENING TITLES - 0’DOWD CASTLE - DAY 6 TOURISTS exploring the picturesque castle, a thirteenth- century structure overlooking the shoreline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the finest surfing destinations in the world, renowned for its two reef breaks. SURFERS riding a massive wave that eventually comes crashing down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large wooden church on a hill. The PARISHIONERS exit. OPENING TITLES end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE -- “Sunday”. LAVELLE and MICHEAL enter. MICHEAL slouching.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: A little too much wine in the chalice again, there, Micheal.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Sorry, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (taking off his chasuble) I’m wondering is this some kind of ploy on your behalf. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: A ploy, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (untying his cincture) A ploy, Micheal. I’ve noticed my stocks of booze appear to be somewhat diminished of late. I’m wondering is this some kind of ploy you're working to cover up for the wine you've been imbibing on the q.t.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I have no idea what you are talking about. LAVELLE removes his stole. Studying MICHEAL all the while

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Father Leary noticed nothing amiss.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Father Leary does not know you as well as I do, Micheal. I’d say he may well underestimate the depths of your Machiavellian chicanery.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: can I go now, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What’s the hurry? Have they called a meeting at Mafia Headquarters? They look blankly at one another.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: On your way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FATHER LEARY is pouring the tea. LAVELLE reading the Sunday newspapers.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: The things you hear in confession these days, it’s depressing.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You have to detach yourself from it. We’re here to provide solace. Your personal feelings don’t come into it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I know that. What d’you take me for? It’s very difficult, though. The mess people make of their lives.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What’s the problem? Without going into details, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Your one with the big black eye on her, have you seen her?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Veronica Brennan. I have, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: She’s an odd one. The things she comes out with. It’s like she’s trying to drag you down into the muck. D’you know what felching is?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I do know what felching is, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I had to look it up.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: This is you not going into details is it?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Oh sorry. Anyway, whatever’s going on with her it’s obviously all gotten out of hand and she’s being knocked around now.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well if you speak to her she’ll raise holy hell and say it was on the basis of something she said to you in the confessional.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I know, I know. We can’t have that. She’1l' get me excommunicated, the cow.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'll have a word with her. Jack as well. Part of my pastoral duties and what-have-you, nothing to do with her confession or anything. See what’s going on.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: And that coloured fella, the Ugandan? He’s one of her lovers, I think. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10 ql

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Simon's from the Ivory Coast.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Right, right. I knew it was that, or Guyana. One of those African countries.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Guyana is in South America.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I don’t think so, now, Father. I was always pretty good at the auld geography. LAVELLE glances at him. Sips his tea. EXT. BEACH - DAY a CLOSE on the skirts of LAVELLE’s black soutane as he walk across the sandy beach. He pauses at the water’s edge and looks out.  12

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a picture -- a fair representation in charcoal o the beach scene, but with the addition of two black figures in a corner of the paper. REVERSE-SHOT ~~ LAVELLE looking over MICHEAL’s shoulder, impressed. MICHEAL ignoring him as he scratches away.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not bad. Surprisingly. I was expecting a daub.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I was thinking, though, Father, what if I was no good at all?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I mean, what if there’s something you really want to do, or something you really want to be, but you're no good at it at all?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s most people’s lives, Michedl. Sadly. He looks up at the beach. Looks back at the picture. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Who are those two lads supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Don’t know. I’ve been reading these ghost stories. Maybe it’s got some- thing to do with that. Spooky. LAVELLE looks at MICHEAL. Pats him on the head. INT. LAVELLE’S ROOM - NIGHT 13 LAVELLE enters, turning on the light, closing the door. The room is spare -- Wooden bed, where his Golden Retriever, Bruno, is sleeping. Grey wool blankets. Whitewashed walls without adornment, save for a crucifix. Cupboard. Writing desk with a large white seashell. Two chairs, one at the desk, one beside the bed. He tosses Moby Dick onto the bed. Bruno yawns. He sits on the chair beside the bed. Thinks. Removes one of his black leather Oxfords. Then the other. Pauses, the second shoe still in his hand. Thinking. Puts down the shoe beside its comrade. Gets up and goes t the desk. Takes off his clerical collar. Pauses. He looks out the window over the writing desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE -- “Monday”. The cathedral is an imposing structure. A handsome modern edifice, with a massive tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BISHOP GARRET MONTGOMERY is eating a large cream scone th size of a baby’s head. A silver tea-set in front of him. His office opulently furnished and decorated.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: So do you know who it was? REVERSE SHOT -- LAVELLE seated opposite. Bereft of tea.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, Your Excellency. I know who it was.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Do you know him well? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well enough.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Knowing this man as you do, do you think it was an idle threat?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: “Not sure” means it’s possible.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. I suppose. MONTGOMERY puts down the scone. Licks his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You didn’t grant him absolution, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: He didn’t ask for it.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well there you have it. The man is not penitent. There is no contrition. He’s threatening to commit a crime, not asking for forgiveness for one. The inviolability of the sacramental seal does not apply.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You’re saying I should go to the police?

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: I'm not saying anything. The choice is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A train exits the station to reveal FIONA LAVELLE. Thirty attractive, her wrists bandaged. A suitcase at her feet. [Note: she has an English accent. ] LAVELLE appears.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me. You made the classic error.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: You're supposed to cut down, not. across. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I don’t know what else to say. They look blankly at one another. LAVELLE opens his arms. FIONA stands up. They embrace. EXT. SLIGO TRAIN STATION - DAY a7 CLOSE on a little red convertible sports car. Bruno in th passenger seat. He barks. REVERSE SHOT -- FIONA and LAVELLE looking at the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Always wanted a fast car. A red one.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I thought you'd already had your mid-life crisis. LAVELLE shoots her a glance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sports car crests a hill and zips by, LAVELLE at the wheel, FIONA beside him, Bruno in the middle. EXT. SPORTS CAR - DAY 1g LAVELLE accelerating ever faster, Bruno barking, FIONA throwing her arms up in delight. EXT. LYNCH’S BAR - DAY 20 Bruno sitting calmly in the car. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - DAY 21 MILO HERLIHY, twenties, polka-dotted bow-tie, an oddly blank look about him. FRANK HARTE, a good-looking older man with a clinical air. Guinnesses in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You're a very nice-looking young woman. REVERSE SHOT -- FIONA and LAVELLE waiting for their drinks. FIONA laughs, glancing at LAVELLE, who smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Thank you. I like your bow-tie.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: It's got polka-dots. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: This is my daughter, Fiona, Milo. She’s over from London.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You're having me on.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’m not having you on. What are you on about?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You're a priest!

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I was married before I became a priest. My wife and I had a child, Fiona. My wife died. And after that I joined the priesthood.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You can do that, can you?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: It would appear so. (noticing FIONA’s bandages) Don’t tell me. You made the classic error.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve already done that gag, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: You're supposed to cut down--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I've already done it, I said.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now, now. BRENDAN LYNCH appears with a Coca-Cola bottle and glass, and a double whiskey. Forty, handsome. Hands the Coke to LAVELLE, the whiskey to FIONA --

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: A drop of the hard stuff for yourself, and a generous serving of the auld water of life to this beautiful and yet troubled--

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh fuck off. LYNCH looks blankly at FIONA. She takes a sip of the whiskey as she moves towards a table. LAVELLE following. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: You have an exceedingly dirty mouth. I like that in a hoor.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Brendan. Now’s not the time. LYNCH looks from FIONA to LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Father. You're the boss. 22 INT. LY¥NCH’S BAR - LATER 22 LAVELLE and FIONA in a little nook. FIONA drinks her whiskey. LAVELLE pushes his Coke bottle around.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: How’s that working out for you?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Oh I haven’t been out on the tear in a good while.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: So you say.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah no, I’ve been a very good lad. And don’t change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What was the subject?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You know what the subject was.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh Daddy, a man, a man. What else.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It's getting to be a habit, honey

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I know. Pathetic. Can't do anything right. She sips her whiskey. LAVELLE takes one of her hands. Rub the bandage with a thumb.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “Razors pain you.”

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (looking at him) “Rivers are damp.” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “Acids stain you. And drugs cause cramp.”

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: “Guns aren’t lawful. Nooses give.”

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “Gas smells awful.”

dialogues.speaker: FIONA/LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “You might as well live.” They smile. LYNCH studies them from the other end of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on various angles of the church’s architecture -- windows, steeple, etc. -- emphasising its simple, unpretentious nature.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Back-to-basics, is what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Simplicity. Lack of ostentation. That kind of thing.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: All your father’s idea. His baby. LAVELLE, FIONA and LEARY are standing to the front and sides of the church. LEARY carrying a box of toys.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: We couldn’t go on with the old one anyways. Falling to pieces. Liable to get someone killed.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It’s a good gimmick, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s not a gimmick.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t mean...

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: They’d call it a rebranding in the advertising world. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I suppose you are a corporate entity, if you look at it in one way.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: It’s the only way to look at it. We provide a product and a service and that’s all there is to it. He strolls away. FIONA smiles wryly. LAVELLE gives a shak of the head. Glances up proudly at the church. 24 EXT. BRENNANS’ HOUSE - DAY 24 VERONICA BRENNAN, thirties, wearing shades, pegging up th linen. White sheets fluttering in the wind. She looks up LAVELLE at the other side of the line. His black soutane fluttering in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Nice shades.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Do they make me look like Jackie 0?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not really, no. VERONICA smiles. Raises the glasses up on her forehead.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: This what you came to gawp at? Nasty, hah?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s an interesting colour. VERONICA lowers the shades and continues with the laundry

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: They say you can find beauty in everything, if you look hard enough.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’d say you can find beauty in most things, but not everything. That's nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Sure what would I know? I’m just an auld washerwoman. The washing that she’s hanging on the line now seems to b comprised solely of items of lingerie.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: See anything you fancy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: If you don’t want to talk to me, that’s fine. I’m not here to compel you to do anything.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: You never know, Father, maybe I'd like to be compelled. Maybe I'd enjoy it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'll have a word with Jack. See what he has to say for himself.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: The Grand Inquisitor, hah? Go on ahead for yourself so. I’m sure he’1l be only too pleased to have someone else to bore the ears off. I stopped listening to his auld shite a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That's how it is, is it? I didn’t realise.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: You thought we were another Grace Kelly and Prince Rainier?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That wasn’t a very happy marriage, so it’s not a great analogy. VERONICA looks at him. Laughs.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Y'know that’s what I've always liked about you, Father. You’re just a little too sharp for this parish. INT. BRENNAN’S BUTCHERS - DAY 25 A meat cleaver comes down hard on a rack of ribs. JACK BRENNAN, forty, in a bloody apron, chopping up the meat.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: (to his ASSISTANT) --Mad fella altogether. Decapitated the two of them. Blood all over the place there was. He chuckles and looks up -- LAVELLE has entered.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Father. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Jack. (glancing at the ASSISTANT, who is serving a CUSTOMER) Could I have a word in private?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: (nervous laugh) Sounds ominous. Where's Johnny Cochran when you need him, hah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carcasses of pigs, and sides of beef, hanging from hooks. The icy breath of LAVELLE and BRENNAN floating between them as they converse --

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: (giggling) . Hope we don’t get locked in. we'll have to make love to keep warm.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I had a word, there, with Veronica, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: You were over to the house? Is everything alright?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Everything’s fine. I mean, no, it’s not fine. Mass on Sunday, with the shades and everything--

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Oh that.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, that. Have you been laying into her or what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Ah that wasn’t me, now. That was that black fella she’s been seeing. Coloured fella, I mean, sorry. Didn't mean to be racist, slip of the tongue.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're saying he beats her up?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Well don’t quote me on it. I mean, that’s what I’m assuming, like. She talks in riddles half the time, I can’t get any sense out of her. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think she’s bi-polar, or lactose- intolerant, one of the two. I never know where I am with her anymore. I'm glad to have her off my hands, to be honest with ya.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Even if this new fella’s knocking her about?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Sure what's that got to do with me? Not everyone can carry the weight of the world, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What about your marriage? The oaths you took?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) The oaths I took! He sees the look LAVELLE gives him and stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Listen, Father, she’s been a lot happier since she’s been seeing him, a lot calmer and more settled down, like. I’m not under surveillance any more either, I can reel in home whatever time I like. So everybody's happy. Now where’s the harm? LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Will I cut you a nice side of beef to be taking home with you, Father? Freshly slaughtered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boots sticking out from underneath a car. The skirts of LAVELLE’s soutane appear. He nudges a boot with his shoe. SIMON ASAMOAH glides out on a car trolley.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Simon.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Hello, Father. (getting up, wiping his hands on a rag) I am rather busy today-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s not about my car. It’s about Mrs Brennan. ASAMOAH reaches for a Coca-Cola bottle and takes a swallow.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're her boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: I fuck her from time to time. Does that make me her boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It does around here.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: She has a lot of boyfriends, I have heard.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Do you want me to confess to adultery? Is that why you are here?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Somebody beat her up.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: She told you I beat her up?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No, she didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Then why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Somebody beat her up. It’s either you or the husband.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: I do not think Jack beat her up. He is not the type.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What is the type? ASAMOAH takes a pack of cigarettes from his pocket and lights one, looking out over the garage forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Some of them like to be hit, you know. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: flinches, 19. 27

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: who?

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: White women. Irish women. Do not ask me why. You would have to be a psychiatrist--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah that’s nonsense. A justification for your own brutality.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: No, no, they like to be hit. In certain...situations. They beg for it, in fact.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: So she got what was coming to her, did she?

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: I was speaking generally.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Oh you were speaking generally. Well I’m speaking specifically. Don’t do it again.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: You cannot tell me what to do. We are not in the Missions now.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Oh the Missions, right--

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Are you going to chop off my hand if I disobey you?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You know your history, that’s grand.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: I like to read. You probably do not think that black people--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah, black people, white people, blah, blah, blah. ASAMOAH looks at him. Flicks his cigarette at him. LAVELL taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Run along now, Father, your sermon is finished. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He slides back under the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEARY is preparing the altar. large Bible set for Mass. 20. 27 LAVELLE exits. 28 LAVELLE glancing through the = *

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: You'd better watch your step there.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: If it was him who was laying into her. You'll have to tread very carefully there. It’s a very sensitive area.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You’1l have to explain this one to me, now, Father, I’m afraid you've lost me completely.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Well the Church can’t be seen to be getting involved in matters of diversity and the like, d’you know.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You mean, like, what if beating her up is one of those ethnic rituals or something? Like when they do that thing when they shake hands?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You’re mocking me, now, I can tell. LAVELLE looks blankly at LEARY. *

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: We have to be very circumspect * in those areas, is all I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'll be very circumspect, Father. Don’t you worry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 29 An older man -~ GERALD RYAN -- is leaning back in a chair deep in thought, a shillelagh between his legs. An American, slightly bohemian, he wears an old brown corduroy suit, blue shirt, black boots. Music playing on an old record player. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He leans forwards over an old manual typewriter. A stack of manuscript pages next to it. Examines the paragraph he has just written. Pauses. The sound of an outboard motor can be heard. He gets up, using the shillelagh, and goes to a pair of large wooden shutters. Opens them to reveal -- LAVELLE upon a stretch of water in an old white wooden speedboat propelled by an outboard motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE is at the stern, a box of provisions beside him - LAVELLE's POV -- the prow of the boat, the island. RYAN framed in the window of the monastic cottage. LAVELLE waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN does not return the wave. Disappears from the window

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE navigates the speedboat to the shoreline of the island, situated four miles off the coast of Sligo. He drags the boat onto the shore, next to an old currach. Hefts the box and tramps up the path to the stone cottage

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN has returned to his seat at the typewriter. LAVELLE appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How is all?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: At death’s door. You?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: The same. Still using the old type- writer, I see. Bit of an affectation.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: My whole life has been an affectation.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s one of those lines that sounds witty but doesn’t actually make much sense.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Caught out agai

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE crosses to the kitchen table and deposits the box

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How’s the latest masterpiece coming? RYAN gets up, struggling with the shillelagh.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Better than Cecelia Ahern, but not as good as Banville.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Sure you could say that about every- body.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: What you got for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE unloads the provisions -- sushi, Maker's Mark bourbon, Green & Black’s organic chocolate --

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Ah, the staff of life. -- and two books: a paperback, Jernigan, by David Gates, and a hardcover, HHhH, by Laurent Binet. RYAN smells the hardcover and handles it reverently.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Need anything else?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: A gun.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Hah?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: A Walther PPK oughtta do it. James Bond’s weapon of choice. Old Adolf killed himself with one in the bunker.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s the plan is it?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I’ve no intention of writhing around in agony for hours on end when the time comes. Or not knowing who I am or where I am. I ain’t going out like that, as the young folks would have it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Romantic nonsense. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Pragmatism.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Where would I get a gun from?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Aww come on, now, gimme a break. You've never been short of guns in this country, have you?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: God, you're awful maudlin today, I must say. 23. 33 RYAN laughs, pops a piece of the chocolate into his mouth INT. LAVELLE’S ROOM - DAY 34 LAVELLE is at his desk, reading Moby Dick. Bruno asleep o the bed. There is a knock at the door. FIONA pops her head in, then enters, closing the door behind her and leaning against it. She glances around.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: You don’t have any photos.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No. I’m in agreement with the Apaches on that score.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: The Apaches?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: The Apaches. The Arapaho.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: The Hunkpapa Sioux! She laughs. LAVELLE smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Not even one of Mum?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t need a photograph to remember your mother.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Memories fade, though. That’s what's so terrible about them.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No they don’t. Not really.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and FIONA are walking briskly up the incline of the road, Bruno running on in front of them.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I should buy a cane.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It'd suit you. You're old beyond your years.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Yeah. It'd give me a feeling of... imperiousness. She looks at him. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: And you could lean on it.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I could lean on it. Reflectively.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Point things out.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Club someone to death with it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: A blunt instrument, yeah. Who, though?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: A certain young man from Rathmines. He glances at her. She is looking at the ground as she walks.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Aren't all instruments blunt?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Flugelhorns? He looks blankly at her. She laughs. On the road ahead, MICHAEL FITZGERALD appears on a fine black thoroughbred. Handsome, suave, Forties. He turns th horse in front of LAVELLE and FIONA.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Who's this now?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: This is my daughter, Fiona. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Oh right. Like a French novel or something. What’s the fella’s name? Bernanos. (to FIONA) Michael Fitzgerald. I bought the Big House, up the road a-ways there, beyond. Fiona nods, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I haven't seen you at Mass lately. I was wondering--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Haven't had the time. I’m actually thinking of building a chapel on the grounds, y’know like in Brideshead Revisited? You could pop round then, freelance, like, save me the trouble. They look blankly at one another. FIONA pats the horse.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Lovely creature.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Really expensive, too. Prime horse flesh. FIONA looks up at him. He smiles a bright flashing smile.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: He's an interesting man, your father.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: A good man. A fine man. No one has a bad word to say about him. Makes me wonder what he’s hiding.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: God, you're a fucking prick--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Oh! Feisty!

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Fiona--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Ah I’m only codding. No offence meant, as they say. Do me a favour, though, Father, and swing by the house one afternoon. (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have a proposition that might interest you.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Yes, really. A financial proposition. That interests you, doesn’t it? Sure it'd be a black day altogether the day the Roman Catholic Church is no longer interested in money, hah? He laughs jovially, gives an Edward G. Robinson salute, and spurs his horse away between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and FIONA are walking along the deserted beach. The waves rolling in. Bruno noses at something in the sand. They pause, look down --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their Pov -- a dead seagull, insects swarming over it. LAVELLE squats. Extends the gull’s wingspan, examining th white feathers, curious.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Dirty thing. He lays it back down. Stands. Turns -- LAVELLE’s POV -- a FIGURE has appeared at the end of the beach, lending a sinister aspect to the scene. LAVELLE strolls on, seemingly unconcerned. FIONA dallies with Bruno. After a moment, LAVELLE glances back -- LAVELLE’s POV -- the FIGURE is approaching.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Let’s head back. He quickens his pace. FIONA and Bruno catching up. After good few strides, he glances back again -- LAVELLE’s POV -- the FIGURE has disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What is it? LAVELLE scans the horizon. Puzzled, but relieved.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Nothing.  27. 37 EXT. STANTON’S HOUSE - NIGHT 37 The door is opened by GERRY STANTON, a Garda Inspector. LAVELLE standing there.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Inspector Stanton.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: The clergy. At this time of the night. When I could be getting up to all sorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE enters, followed by STANTON. A young man buckling up his jeans descends the stairs. This is LEO MACARTHUR.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: (talking like Leo Gorcey from The Dead End Kids) Hey, Fada! Whaddaya hear, whaddaya say!

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I didn’t realise you had company.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Ah sure, it’s only little Leo. LEO smirks as he zips up his fly. * 38A INT. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT 38a * LEO bending over a jukebox to select a tune. LAVELLE * sitting on a couch, glancing at photographs of Stanton. * STANTON with a brandy balloon. *

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You checking out my ass, Fada?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What? No--

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: He’s only messing with you, Father. What can I do for you? He sips his brandy. LAVELLE glances at LEO. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: I’ve nothing to hide from Leo. Have I, Leo?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Your life is an open book, Gerry. Like your ass. Flanagan & Allen’s “Run, Rabbit, Run” begins to play. LEO dances as if he were a little rabbit. STANTON laughs.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Is this a police matter, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No, it’s a personal...a personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: It’s a personal a personal thing.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You look worried, Fada. My advice? Take it on the lamaster. You don’t wanna drop in for the phonus-bolonus and wind up with a sock in the kisser. Get me? LAVELLE looks blankly at LEO.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: He’s not in the mood, Leo.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Maybe I can cheer up the old sour- puss. I’1l show ya a good time, Fada. Good Time Leo, that’s me! Although it'll be extra if I let ya wear the cassock. I know what, you holy-rollers are like when ya get goin’! Hell’s bells! LAVELLE looks blankly at LEO. LEO and STANTON look at eac other and laugh. LEO grabs his leather jacket.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I’m oudda heah! He tap-dances out the door.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: He’s a character, hah? What’s troubling you, Father? You seem agitated.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I need a favour.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a Webley Revolver, circa 1920, laid out in a beautiful velvet case.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: My great-grandfather’s. Said he took it off one of the Cairo Gang when they shot them all on Bloody Sunday. The first Bloody Sunday, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ever had call to use it?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Yeah. I killed a man with it once. In the Wicklow mountains. He hefts the gun, sighting along it, straight at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What case was that?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Ah he was just pissing me off, like. LAVELLE is not sure if he’s joking. STANTON hands him the gun. Passes him a carton of bullets. LAVELLE flips open the chamber. Loads it.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Somebody been threatening you, Father? What have you been up to, now? (with a smirk) Not you as well, hah? LAVELLE flips shut the chamber. Sights along the revolver straight at STANTON. STANTON looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: What did you say you wanted it for, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I didn’t say. He replaces the revolver in the case.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: I'd say you wanted it for your dog. The dog’s dying, it’s in pain, you're worried you might have to put it out of its misery one of these days. Isn’t that right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE looks round at STANTON. Understands --

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: My dog's dying. It’s in pain. I’m worried I might have to put it out of its misery one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: An act of compassion, hah? Well I can’t argue with that. I’m a compassionate man meself. 40 EXT. STANTON’S HOUSE - NIGHT 40 LAVELLE and STANTON exit the house. LAVELLE carrying the case.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: I had one of those, y’know. Early on.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: One of what?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Paedophile priest. Twenty years ago now this was, in Dublin. Young girl made a complaint. A rape.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Ah sure, what d’ya think happened? I arrested the bastard and forty- eight hours later I was packing my bags and making my way out West.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: They moved you on?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Reassigned, yeah. LAVELLE gets into his car.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What happened to him?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: I was told they were sending him to one of the missions overseas. Africa. He could do whatever he wanted over there, I suppose. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well thanks, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Like the man in the dicky bow says, Father, “Protect yourself at all times!” LAVELLE drives off. INT. RECTORY (FIONA’S ROOM) - DAY 41 TITLE -- “Tuesday”. FIONA awakens, wearing a man’s shirt. Sits up in bed, contemplative. Through a window, LAVELLE can be seen walking away with a fishing rod, Bruno at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA raises the hem of her skirt to her thighs and steps down into the cool clear water. Bruno watching her. She paddles out to where LAVELLE is standing in waders, fly-fishing, the skirt of his soutane floating out over the water.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: How long you been at this craic?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Last coupla years. Supposed to be therapeutic.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Maybe I should take it up.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should. (pause) Have you been seeing anyone, in London?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I’m assuming you mean professionally rather than-—

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah come on now, let’s stop with all that carry-on. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: If you can’t talk to me, you should talk to someone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I suppose I should. A further silence between them.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Enjoying yourselves?! LAVELLE and FIONA look up to see FATHER LEARY looking dow on them from the nearby bridge, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: We are indeed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely day

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It is indeed!

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: (esoterically) Stamps! He looks at them a moment longer, then disappears over th bridge.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: That‘s the future of the priesthood. LAVELLE looks at her. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE is distributing hymnals to all the pews. Suddenly he senses something, looks round -- MILO HERLIHY is standing there, having materialised seemingly out of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Milo.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: I need to speak to you, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Take a pew. Literally. HIGH-ANGLE SHOT -- They sit in separate pews. A large wooden cross looms above them.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Why do people kill themselves, Father? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why do people kill themselves. That’s jumping in at the deep end. Lots of reasons, I suppose. Why do you think yourself?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: I dunno. The drink. Depression. Lack of sex, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're a presentable young man. I wouldn’t have thought you'd have too much trouble in that area.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: I don’t have the gift of the gab. Never had it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: And it’s making you feel suicidal?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: More bored than anything else. It’s either committing suicide or joining the Army.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Those are pretty drastic choices, either way.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You can learn a trade if you join the Army.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You can learn a trade if you don’t join the Army.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: You can experience more of life.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You think you can become a more authentic person by fighting in a war? By killing people?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIBY
dialogues.text: You're against me joining the Army, is what I’m sensing.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Let's put it this way, I’ve always felt there was something inherently psychopathic about someone who joins the Army in peacetime. As far as I’m concerned, people join the Army because they want to find out what (MORE) (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: it’s like to kill someone. I don’t think that is an inclination that should be encouraged in modern society, do you? HERLIHY shrugs, non-committal.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ didn’t think so either. And the commandment “Thou Shalt Not Kill” does not have an asterisk beside it, referring you to the bottom of the page, where there's a list of instances where it is okay to kill people.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: What about self-defence?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Well that’s a tricky one, alright. But we’re hardly being invaded, now, are we?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: The War on Terror has no borders.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t think Sligo is too high on al-Qaida’s agenda, Milo, do you?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Who knows what goes on in the Muslim mind? (pause) I have had murderous feelings, though, I have to admit. Not getting laid. It’s starting to make me feel really angry towards women. And so I thought, well, if I joined the Army, those inclinations as you call them would be seen as a plus. On your application, like. I mean, they don’t come right out and say that’s what they’re looking for, in the advertisements, it’s all about seeing the world and all that shite, but I would assume that wanting to murder someone would be like having a degree in engineering or something, y’know? It would outweigh my lack of qualifications.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Right. (pause) Do you use pornography at all? I’m assuming-- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Ah, I feel I’ve exhausted all the possibilities of pornography.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: All of them?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Well nearly all of them. I’m onto transsexual pornography at the moment. LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Chicks with dicks, y’know? LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on HERLIEY and LAVELLE. HERLIHY putting on goggles.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe there’s a simpler solution. Leave home and go somewhere your chances of meeting available young women with loose morals are increased proportionately.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Sligo Town, you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No. I was thinking more Dublin, London, New York-~

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: New York? I'd only end up getting the Aids. Knowing my luck. to reveal HERLIHY is astride a motorbike.

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Thanks for taking the time to talk to me, Father. I can’t say it’s been of much help, but it’s good to get these things out in the open, I suppose. He zooms off down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 45 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bright blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Pull! Two fluorescent orange targets appear in the sky and are summarily shot to pieces -- FITZGERALD, in a corduroy three-piece suit and a red cap, standing next to a voice-activated clay pigeon trap, ejects the shells from his shotgun and quickly reloads.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Pull! Two more targets are launched -- FITZGERALD hits both. Ejects the shells. Pauses in the ac of reloading -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FITZGERALD’s POV -- LAVELLE is standing on the path leading up to the mansion. FITZGERALD clicks shut the shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FITZGERALD fixes himself a large whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: They've all left me, you know. That's why the place is so empty. Like a tomb. LAVELLE is wandering about the opulently fu: decorated room, examining various objets d’ sparkling water in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Who’s left you?
46 the crest of a7 wnished and art, a glass of The wife. The kids. Even Consuela, and she’s from Ecuador. You'd think she wouldn't have a lot of options, but apparently not.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well I’m sorry to hear that. FITZGERALD shrugs, takes a swallow of his drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You mentioned a financial proposition?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I want to make amends. Do penance for past sins. Although I suppose all sins are past, aren’t they, o: they wouldn’t be sins, they’d jus be evil thoughts floating around in your mind. Why do you wear the auld soutane, by the way? Trying to make a statement or something? oa rt LAVELLE looks blankly at him. Sips his water. FITZGERALD smirks. Shoots back a cuff to reveal a gold Ta Heuer watch at his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: This watch, now. This watch is making a statement. It’s a Tag He Really expensive. uer. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Are you going to get to the point, Mr Fitzgerald, or are you just going to ramble on--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Let me ask you something. What do you see when you look at me? LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I‘ll tell you what you see. You see a handsome, sophisticated, eminent man in the prime of his life. A Colossus, let’s say. A Colossus who once bestrode the world of high finance and became profoundly influential in certain spheres, not to say inordinately wealthy, not to say sickeningly wealthy, let’s face it. (knocks back the whiskey, pours another) Sure I can’t tempt you?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I‘ll stick to the water.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I heard you liked a drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I liked it too much.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: There’s no such thing as too much, there’s only not enough. LAVELLE exits the room. INT. GRAND HALLWAY - DAY 47a LAVELLE is examining a display of antique and contemporar firearms. FITZGERALD joins him.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Where was I?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Talking about money, what else.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Now now.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Got out in time, did you? Before it all came crashing down? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: ‘Twas the perfect getaway, Father. They say charges are going to be filed against me, for various so- called irregularities, but sure the Guards are always threatening guff like that. They’d have to charge half the financiers in Ireland, and half the bank managers along with them, and troop into government then and charge those cunts as well, and we all know full well that’s not going to happen. No, there’1l be no punishment forthcoming for a man such as myself. There never is. Still, I do feel a modicum of guilt about the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: A modicum. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Well. I feel like I ought to feel guilty. And sure isn’t that the same thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a painting pauses in Holbein’s The Ambassadors. LAVELLE front of it. FITZGERALD at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I love this one. Really expensive. Not sure what it’s supposed to mean, though.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why does it have to mean anything?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Everything has to mean something, otherwise what’s the point? Of course, I don’t have to know what it means. I own it. That’s enough.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That's all that matters? Ownership? Possession?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: How much land does the Church own? How much gold?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That's the Church, that’s not me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: But you're a representative of the Church, are you not?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: If you say so.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I do say so. I think you’re a very judgemental man, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. But I try not to be.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: You think I have no feelings? You think I don’t care about--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I think you don’t want to do penance at all. I think you asked me here to make fun of me. But when you do want to do penance, sincerely, you can give me a call, at any time, and I’ll try my best to help you. He walks towards the front door.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: You know, I could piss on this. (gesturing at the painting) I said I loved it, but I don’t. It doesn’t mean anything to me. I could take it down right now and piss on it. Do you want me to do that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why would I want you to do that?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I don’t know. So I could have some kind of spiritual revelation? Some fucking epiphany?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well I don’t know, now. People like you have pissed on everything else, I suppose, so why not that, too? FITZGERALD nods. Grins. Takes down the painting and drops it onto the floor. Looks at LAVELLE as he opens his flies LAVELLE goes out the front door. FITZGERALD pisses on the painting.  49 50 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE’s POV -- a MAN walks out of the sun, his image blurred, raises a gun and fires, point-blank --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE lying supine, a straw hat over his face. He jolts Pauses. Removes the hat. Sits up and looks around. FIONA is reading H P Lovecraft and eating an apple. The remains of a picnic close by. Bruno sleeping. Behind them, a massive Ice Age boulder, split in two, in the middle of a field.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How long was I out?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Ages. Eons. He nods. Glances round at the split-rock.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you the story of Fionn Mac Cumhaill and another big strong lad named Cicsatéin? They were up the top:

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: They were up the top of the Ox Mountains. Cicsatéin challenged Fionn to throw a boulder into the sea at Easkey, claiming he couldn’t do it. Fionn accepted the challenge. Cicsatéin’s boulder landed on the Easkey shore, where it created such waves that the sea hasn't been the same since, which is why the Easkey coastline is internationally renowned for surfing. Fionn’s boulder fell short and landed here. Fionn drew his sword and split the rock in two. It's said that should anyone be foolhardy enough to pass through the rock three times, the two halves will come together and they will be squashed into tiny little lumps. Unceremoniously.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not a lot of poetry in that recital. Not a lot of romance.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I’m sick to death of romance. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE studies her as she continues to read.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How’s the book?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I am filled with cosmic horror.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I know the feeling. FIONA smiles, despite herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moon shining over a monolithic hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRANK HARTE, who happens to be a doctor, watching LAVELLE fussing with the contents of a black Gladstone bag.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: You have your totems, I see.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: French couple. Head on. She was totally unscathed. He got fucked.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Wrong side of the road?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Car full of young ones hit them. Drunk, of course. LAVELLE places a stole about his neck.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Five including the Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Dear God.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Marine biologist he was. That's where I’d like to be. Under the sea.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Where are the young ones? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: The morgue. Best place for them.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Every life is sacred, Frank, for God’s sake.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Some are less sacred than others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAURENT ROBERT lies dying, his face and body bandaged, tubes sticking out of him. TERESA, his wife, holding his hand, her mascara wet around her eyes. LAVELLE looks at them both. DISSOLVE through CLOSE-UPS of LAVELLE, TERESA, LAURENT.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Through this holy anointing may the Lord in his love and mercy help you with the grace of the Holy Spirit. DISSOLVE through CLOSE-UPS of LAVELLE’s fingers, the oil, and LAURENT’s forehead, as the anointing of the forehead takes place.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: amen. DISSOLVE through CLOSE-UPS of LAVELLE’s fingers, the oil, and LAURENT’s hands, as the anointing of the hands takes place.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: May the Lord who frees you from sin save you and raise you up.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on the face of Christ. A stained-glass window. The faces of LAVELLE and TERESA.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Have you performed the Last Rites many times?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. Usually with older people, of course. You have time to prepare for it. Everybody knows what’s coming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: It is easier?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s never easy. More understandable, let’s say. Less unfair.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Unfair.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Situations like this one, people are shocked. The randomness of it. They curse God. Curse their fellow man. They lose their faith, in some cases.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: They lose their faith? It must not have been much of a faith to begin with, if it is so easy for them to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. But what is faith, at the end of the day? For most people it’s the fear of death, nothing more than that. And if that’s all it is, then it’s very easy to lose.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: (after a pause) When we are children we are told to say our prayers. Our parents tell us, our teachers. Then we grow up and we think people who say their prayers are stupid. They’re ridiculous. Unless we want money, of course, or a good job, or we have a child who is sick, or a lover who is dying Then we are allowed to pray again. Then it is okay.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. But the prayer must be answered.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Yes, the prayer must be answered. And if the prayer is not answered then there is no God and it is all a lie. If God does not pay attention to us, because we are so important, then God does not exist.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. We must be paid attention to. (pause) He was a good man, your husband? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Yes, he was a good man. We had a very good life together. We loved each other very much. And now he has gone. That is not unfair, that is just what happened. But many people do not live good lives, and they do not feel love. That is what is unfair. I feel sorry for them.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Will you say a prayer with me, Teresa?

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Hail Mary, full of grace-- ‘TERESA/LAVELLE -the Lord is with thee. Blessed art thou amongst women, and blessed is the fruit of thy womb, Jesus. Holy Mary, Mother of God, pray for us sinners, now and at the hour of our death. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HARTE is smoking a cigarette. LAVELLE steps outside.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Finished with all your gobbledegook? LAVELLE does not acknowledge the insult.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: How’s she holding up?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: She’s a strong woman.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Good-looking, too. I could be in there. I have a thing for widows, did I ever tell you?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I think you might have done. Your material is getting a little stale after all.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Ah sure, the atheistic doctor, it’s a clichéd part to play. There’s not that many good lines. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One part humanism to nine parts gallows humour. Playing you, though, that might be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Playing me. Who’s “me”?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: The good priest. They look at each other. Then HARTE looks up at the moon.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: I heard a story once about one of the astronauts who slept on the moon. He had a dream where he was driving one of those moon buggies across the surface of the moon, and he rode and he rode until he came upon another buggy that was exactly like his. He looked into the face of the man who was driving the buggy and he saw that it was himself. and his double said to him, “I’ve been waiting for you for thousands of years.” And that was the end of the dream. LAVELLE studies him. HARTE turns aside, opening the door

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Excuse me, won’t you. I have to go kill somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE -- “Wednesday”. MICHEAL is in his vestments, swinging a thurible to and fro, the incense rising. LAVELLE moves in and out of frame, preparing for Mass.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: They're mad auld things thurifers, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s a thurible. You're a thurifer.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I’m a thurifer? (pause) Thurifer. Funny word. (pause) I like the smell of this stuff. It gets me high.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What do you know about “high”? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I know plenty.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Micheal, why did you become an altar boy? I ask this because it can safely be said, without fear of contradiction, that you have no vocation whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: My Ma told me they give you money at weddings and christenings.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I see. It was purely a moneymaking scheme on your part.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Yeah. To pay for my oils.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: To pay for your oils.

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Yeah. And I haven’t had a sovereign off anybody. People round here are pure mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and RYAN walking through the remains of an early Irish monastic settlement. They enter the cemetery. RYAN leaning heavily on his shillelagh.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Is this where you want to be buried?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Why in the hell would I want to be buried in this godforsaken place?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) Where then? Pere Lachaise? Next to dear old Oscar?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: No. Next to Apollinaire and Max Ophiils.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Oh very fancy, I must say. (pause) I have your gun for you, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Yeah right. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I do so. A Webley. Circa 1920. Still in good working order, though. Or so I've been told by a man who would know.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Hand it over, then.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t have it on me.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I knew it. Worried I might follow through with it, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You might take a potshot at me, for all I know.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Why would I do that? What have you ever done to me except talk garbage?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Sure that doesn’t mean anything. Bloody idiots can’t even be bothered coming up with a reason for murder these days. They wake up in a foul mood and it’s bang bang bang.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Oh I don’t know about that. Some people have very good reasons.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. CONFESSIONAL
dialogues.text: CLOSE on FIONA and LAVELLE. The shadow of the grille playing across their faces. DISSOLVE THROUGH --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: There was a Japanese writer committed suicide. He wrote out a list beforehand of all the famous suicides throughout history. He included Christ.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Sounds like a smartarse.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: In the Middle Ages they would've said I was possessed by demons.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe you were. Maybe they were nearer the mark back then. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: You think what happened was un- important. Insignificant in the great scheme of things. To provoke such a reaction. But what may mean nothing to you may be very important to me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'd never say it was unimportant. I'd just say that the choices you make when you're thirty are not the same choices you'd make when you're sixty.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: That’s irrelevant. Every moment of living has its own logic.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Maybe so. Maybe you're right, there. I'd have to have a think about that. (pause) It’s a tired old argument, I suppose, but what about those you leave behind.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I belong to myself, not to anybody else.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: True. False. FIONA smiles. LAVELLE waits, attentive.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Funny, in the old days it was the priests who'd tell you you were sick. Now it’s the psychiatrists. (pause) You know Freud had cancer of the gums at the end of his life. The smell from his mouth was so bad even his own dog wouldn't go near him. He asked his doctor, an old friend of his, to give him an overdose of morphine. Which he did.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not a big fan of Freud. Never have been.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (after a pause) The absurdity of existence versus the absurdity of nothing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Tough choice when you put it like that. FIONA laughs. There is silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: You'll tell me it would’ve been a mortal sin, I suppose. Would I have suffered eternal damnation, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) God is great. The limits of His mercy have not been set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD escorts LAVELLE around the prison.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Which of the lads are you here to see, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Freddie Joyce. The GUARD pauses and looks at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Freddie Joyce? He’s--

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I know who he is. What in the hell d’ya want to see him for?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: He’s an old pupil of mine. He asked to see me. The GUARD stares at LAVELLE. Then proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREDDIE JOYCE at a table. Thirties, thin, hair all over the place, hands cuffed behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Y'know I’ve asked them to hang me. LAVELLE opposite. A Bible and rosary in front of him. The room is gloomy, lit by a single lightbulb. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: There’s no capital punishment in Ireland, Freddie, as you well know. Why do you want them to hang you?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: ‘Cause that’s the way Lesley Ryan died.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're saying you feel remorse.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’m not a monster. Do I look like a monster?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What do monsters look like?

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: “To thine own self be true,” they say. Well I was, and look where it’s got me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: They've never really thought that one through, you're right.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: It's a terrible world. when you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes it is. And a beautiful one.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: It wasn’t for me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're not the whole world.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: That’s a matter of opinion. He watches a cockroach scuttling around in a corner of th ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I’m reading Paradise Lost at the moment. You know that one? “Better to reign in Hell--”

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “--than serve in Heaven.” Yeah. Yeah I know that quote. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You're making fun of me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Have I hurt your feelings? JOYCE stretches his arms, flexes his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I had the cops in here the other day. The third degree. Wanting to go over all the gory details.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Which I’m sure you were only too happy to provide.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: They’re obsessed with cannibalism. “what did it taste like?” Told ‘em it tasted like pheasant. Bit gamey.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Good for you. Make a joke about it. JOYCE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why were they--

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: Same as always. They want to know where the last one is. The one I connected up. The one they never found.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why can’t you tell them, Freddie? Give the family some kind of peace.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I wanted to, Father, but for the life of me I can’t remember. I know it was out in the woods somewhere--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Where did I leave my keys.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: No. I wasn’t in my right mind. The LSD. It was like a fairytale--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah you said all that at the trial. It's getting kind of tiresome now.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: She was a lovely girl...Y’know she told me she’d been abused before. So I said, “Well once more won't make any difference, then.” (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He laughs to himself. LAVELLE reaches for the rosary. Fingers the beads absently.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You see the light go out in their eyes and you become God.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No you don’t. No. You don’t. JOYCE smirks. Watches LAVELLE fingering the beads.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: “The woods are lovely, dark and deep, but I have promises to keep.” (with a laugh) It’s like that joke. You know that joke? There’s a fella with this young lad driving into the woods, right. It’s getting darker and darker the deeper into the woods they go, and the young lad says, “I’m getting scared, Mister.” And the fella says--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah I do know that joke. I’ve heard it before.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: You're always one step ahead, aren't you, Father? It’s like when we were back in school--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (angrily) Why am I here? For the love of God.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I just wanted somebody to talk to.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t think you feel any guilt whatsoever about anything you've done.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: (suddenly sobbing) I do, Father, IT do (sniffling; wiping his nose on his shoulder) I believe what the Bible teaches. I believe if I repent my sins 1/11 be forgiven and I’1l be able to go up to Heaven and see those girls and tell them how sorry I am, and I’1l hug them and 1/11 kiss them and I'll love them with a real true love, and have no desire to hurt (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: them in any way. (sobbing again) God made me, didn’t he? I mean, didn’t he? He understands me. He must do. LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: JOYCE
dialogues.text: I mean, don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I think if God can’t understand you, Freddie, no one can. EXT. LYNCH’S BAR - EVENING 61 LYNCH is keeping up a ping-pong ball with a table tennis bat. The sound of Irish music can be heard. LAVELLE appears, nods to LYNCH.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: You know they’re foreclosing on me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Who? The banks. Who else.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: How come I never hear your mob preaching about that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: All these bankers who've brought the country to its knees. Still throwing people out of their homes, though, when they can’t make their payments. Never hear your mob talking about that. Those are sins, too, aren’t they?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes they are.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Ah sure, I suppose when you have a history of screwing the Jews out of their money and collaborating with the Nazis then, it’s like the pot calling the kettle black, hah? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, I suppose it is. Been getting the full use out of your library card, there, Brendan.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: The library's been shut down, did you not hear? Cutbacks. INT. L¥NCH’S BAR - EVENING 62 A rowdy CEILIDH BAND is playing on a dais in a corner. FIONA waves to LAVELLE as he enters. Then returns to her conversation with some SURFERS. LAVELLE notices JACK and VERONICA BRENNAN at a table together, not speaking. SIMON ASAMOAH is the other side o the room, talking to a blonde SURFER CHICK. STANTON and HARTE are knocking back shots at the bar. STANTON sees LAVELLE. Raises his shot glass in salute. FATHER LEARY is talking to a handsome blond SURFER DUDE. MILO HERLIHY is sitting on his own with a Guinness. LAVELLE sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You not dancing, Milo?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: I don’t like this music.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What music do you like?

dialogues.speaker: HERLIHY
dialogues.text: Dolly Parton.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Dolly Parton’s good, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONICA is snorting cocaine, while HARTE waits his turn, singing like The Count from Sesame Street --

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: “Bones, bones, bones, bones, bones inside of you!” LAVELLE enters. Pauses. HARTE and VERONICA turn.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: It’s purely medicinal, Father. VERONICA laughs. LAVELLE betrays no emotion. Exits.  56. 64 INT. LYNCH’S BAR - NIGHT 64 LAVELLE and LEARY are standing at the bar, nursing Diet * Cokes. STANTON seated beside them, bleary-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: How was your man, Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s been a tough day, let’s put it that way.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: How can you ever hope to connect with someone like that?
