dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: “Nothing human is alien to me.” Or shouldn’t be, anyways.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I can’t see the point in it myself. Dead loss.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Who are you talking about? Not Freddie Joyce?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I visited him in prison today.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Prisoners deserve spiritual guidance as much as anyone else. Maybe more 50.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Is that right? So they can find God and then say God has absolved them of all their sins and what they did didn’t really matter anyways ‘cause now they’re saved?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Something like that, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: (to STANTON) Calm down. You don’t know what you're talking about. STANTON looks blankly at LEARY. Then suddenly clamps a * hand over his face and shoves him backwards -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sending him flying into the table at which sit JACK and VERONICA BRENNAN, glasses shattering —-

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Jesus, lads, mind the drinks, for Christ’s sake! HARTE, HERLIHY, ASAMOAH, FIONA and the SURFERS look round Then continue on as if nothing has happened. LAVELLE and STANTON look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: He’s had that coming a long time. You know yourself. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - LATER 65 LAVELLE is standing next to FIONA, watching HARTE dancing with the SURFER CHICK. *

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Fine-looking man.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'd watch yourself around him.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh I gave up the cocaine a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You took cocaine? She shrugs. She smiles. *

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: How about a dance? Or what did * they call it in your day, a jive? *

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah now, I’m not cut out--

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Ah come on. * She hauls him onto the dance-floor. * HIGH-ANGLE SHOT -- LAVELLE and FIONA dancing together, * alongside HARTE and the SURFER CHICK, VERONICA and ASAMOAH, and OTHERS. *  58. 66 INT. LYNCH’S BAR - LATER 66 VERONICA pauses beside LAVELLE at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Father, for I have sinned.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Say ten Hail Marys and an Our Father.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Ah, I’ve sinned more than that.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Make an ascent of Croagh Patrick, then, on your knees.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: On my knees, is it? What made you say that? She looks blankly at him. He finishes his Diet Coke. She laughs and moves on. LYNCH appears, inside the bar.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Your church is on fire.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Brendan, I'm not in the mood-~

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Your church is on fire. LAVELLE looks up -- LYNCH is gazing straight past him -- LAVELLE looks round -- REVERSE SHOT -- through a large rectangular window, the church can be seen burning at the top of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The burning church. LAVELLE arriving at the scene. Followed by OTHERS from the bar. LAVELLE is frozen to the spot for a moment, stunned. The flames look beautiful in the dark of the night as they lick up the sides of the wooden structure. 67a INT. CHURCH - NIGHT 67a A burning beam collapses. The pews burn. Wooden plinths around two statues burn. The Stations of the Cross burn.  678 7c 59.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACK BRENNAN runs up to LAVELLE --

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I’ve called the fire brigade, Father. For all the good it’l1 do. He stares at the fire, his mouth open, enthralled. HARTE lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: They won't get here in time. LEARY looks on, a hand to his head in shock. LAVELLE circles the church, realising there is nothing to be done, the entire building is afire.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t anybody see? FIONA finds him, pulls at his sleeve --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Come away, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why didn’t anybody see? MILO HERLIHY laughs childishly, a pint of Guinness still in his hand. VERONICA BRENNAN and SIMON ASAMOAH glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: You'll probably get the blame for this. They laugh. Turn away from the scene. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - NIGHT 67c STANTON and LYNCH look on dispassionately.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Professional job. I’1l say that for them.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Any fool can start a fire, for fuck’s sake.  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH-ANGLE SHOT -- LAVELLE looking on impotently as the timbers in the church start to give way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE -- “Thursday”. HIGH-ANGLE SHOT -- LAVELLE looking on at the blackened embers. FIONA, STANTON and LEARY nearby.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: So now we/re being burnt out.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Who'd do a thing like this?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Somebody with a grudge against the Church, obviously.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Sure that could be half the country.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Burning the place down, though?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: People are angry. They’ve a lot to be angry about.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Unless there’s a personal angle. LAVELLE glances at him. FIONA noticing the look.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: How d’you mean?

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Nobody with a grudge against you, Father, no?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Why would anyone have a grudge against us? STANTON shrugs. Toes the embers with his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Maybe this is the future, hah? Maybe it’1l all be ruins one day. Maybe one day kids will say to their parents in amazement, They used to believe in what? An auld lad up in (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STANTON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: the sky? And if we’re good we'll go to Heaven? And if we're bad well go to Hell?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: y'know for a policeman you seem to know very little about human nature.

dialogues.speaker: STANTON
dialogues.text: Maybe you’re right. Sure you'd know more than me. Don’t touch anything, now, I'll have to get the forensic boys down, the supercilious pricks. He exits. LAVELLE, LEARY and FIONA stand in silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: We'll have to rebuild it, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Maybe use bricks next time, might be a good idea. She looks at LAVELLE. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Sure that’1l take ages.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Is there somewhere you have to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BISHOP MONTGOMERY is on his cellphone, strolling along a path, beautiful flowers arrayed on every side --

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: --Inspector Stanton’s handling all that, as far as I’m aware, you'll have to speak to him...It looks like arson, yes...Young lads losing the head, I suppose, sure isn’t that always the way?...No, we haven’t had any trouble before now...Thank you. Goodbye. He flips shut the cellphone and pauses in front of a larg rosebush.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You'll have the press and TV people round at some point. * (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE has been trailing in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No doubt. MONTGOMERY inhales the scent of the roses.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know who it is. MONTGOMERY turns and looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: You said you did.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I have no evidence it’s the same man.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: It’s the same man. Takes a lot of nerve to burn down a church. Helps if you have a burning sense of grievance. If you'll pardon the... He walks on. LAVELLE following.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: We have to ask ourselves, What does this man want? Well, he wants to be loved, of course. We all want to be loved. Failing that, he wants to be admired. Failing that, he wants to be feared. And failing that, he wants to be hated and despised. We should beware the man who wants to be hated and despised. Don’t you think?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I think you read that in a book. MONTGOMERY smiles. They move on.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I think he wants to stir up some sort of feeling in others, that’s true. He doesn’t want to be ignored anymore. He wants to make contact.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Well he made contact alright. Who is it? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE looks blankly at him. MONTGOMERY nods.

dialogues.speaker: MONTGOMERY
dialogues.text: Those roses’1] want cutting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONICA emerges from the water to find LAVELLE waiting for her.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Is this about the coke? I can take it or leave it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Most people can. The only ones who can’t, had problems to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: We shouldn’t write them off, though, the ones who had problems to begin with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VERONICA dries her hair with a towel. Studies him.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What do you want to do with your life, Veronica?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Nothing. “Consider the lilies of the field, how they grow. They toil not, neither do they spin.”

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s a very nice quotation. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They look VERONICA g) 64. 70

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Ah sure everybody knows that one.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s hackneyed, yeah. Like “Turn the other cheek,” and “Judge not, lest ye be judged.” at each other.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: I'd like to be an actress, maybe. I’ve got an absent father and a domineering mother.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well it’s a start. When did your father leave?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: He didn’t leave, he was killed.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: He was murdered?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Hunting accident. (pause) Completely random. (pause) So there’s no use persevering, Father. I’m a lost cause.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No one’s a lost cause, Veronica. lances at him, then strides away.  65. INT. RECTORY (STUDY) - DAY n FITZGERALD with a big smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Dreadful business, I must say. Some little blackguard running riot, I wouldn’t wonder. He is standing between two desks, jingling the change in his pockets. LAVELLE at one desk. LEARY at the other.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Sure what can you do, in this day and age.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: True dat. (to LAVELLE) Sorry about the other day, Father. That was the drink talking.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Well it follows on from what I was saying. And it seems more necessary now than ever. (producing a cheque-book) I'd like to make a donation.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: (getting up) Oh that’s grand!

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: To salve your conscience?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Surely that’s in the nature of all philanthropy? The expiation of guilt?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I’m sure you have nothing major to feel guilty about, Mr Fitzgerald. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Oh you'd be surprised, Father. And call me Michael.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Michael it is. Any charity is always gratefully received.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I know. I believe that’s Church doctrine. And the Church needs all the help it can get these days, hah?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Why would you say that?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Well, y’know, what with all the compensation that’s been paid out over the years. LEARY’s superficial smile freezes on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I read where it’s up to two billion now. And that’s just the Yanks. And sure we all know they weren’t the worst, now, don’t we? LAVELLE looks blankly at him. Then blankly at LEARY to gauge his reaction.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I don’t know about that, now. And anyways, most of those cases were forty or fifty years ago. Raking up old ground, it’s always seemed to me. It’s time to forgive and forget.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Oh I agree with you, I agree with you. It’s time to move on. What’s past is past. Et cetera, et cetera.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Ah...Would you like a cup of tea, Michael, or something--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: No, no, can’t stop. He sits in LEARY’s chair. Waves the cheque-book --

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: What are we talking? Ten? Twenty?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Twenty thousand euros, yeah. LEARY perches himself on the desk. Excited. *

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Why that’d be grand. That/d help with getting the initial building work off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Twenty it is, then. (producing a beautiful Pierrot White fountain pen) This is a David Oscarson pen. Really expensive.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: It’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why not make it fifty? FITZGERALD and LEARY look at him. FITZGERALD smiles. *

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Ah now, Father-~

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: If money’s no object, make it fifty.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Why not make it a hundred? LEARY’s jaw drops open. He looks at LAVELLE. *

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Means nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I know it doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand euros, Father. For your pet project. what do you say to that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I say, Thank you, Mister Fitzgerald. FITZGERALD grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA is playing with Bruno, rubbing his belly, flopping his ears around. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Good dog. Aren’t you a good dog. Yes you are. LAVELLE appears. He watches them in silence, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. SLIGO TOWN RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and FIONA eating.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s my fault.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: How is it your fault what some crazy person--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I should have done something. Said something.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (after a pause) What was Stanton was getting at?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: If I could tell you I would. You know that.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I thought I was the one supposed to be in trouble, not you. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How's the fish? They look up to see VERONICA BRENNAN, coked up, standing over them. Glamorously dressed, a gin-and-tonic in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Too many little bones.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Isn’t that always the way. She grabs a chair and sits at their table. FIONA looks at her, then at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: I’m not stopping. Meeting the fella.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're informing me of your adultery in advance? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Isn’t that more honest than in the confessional when it’s all done-and- dusted and there’s nothing you can do about it?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What are you expecting him to do about it now?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Stop me from committing a mortal sin.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You have to stop yourself. I can’t stop you.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Then what good are you at all? FIONA shoots another look at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: You're right, though. I mean, who are you to lecture anyone when it comes to sex?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: He has as much right as anyone else--

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: I don’t think virgins have any call to be dictating-—

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What makes you think I’m a virgin? Fiona’s my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Oh I thought she was just some young one you were fiddling around with. LAVELLE almost flinches.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh you bitch. LAVELLE looks at VERONICA with utter disgust. She notices this, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: You want to hit me now, don’t ya? Go on. Hit me. LAVELLE looks blankly at her. She grins. Suddenly, FIONA hits her a massive slap to the face -.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: OTHER DINERS glance around. One of whom is LEO MACARTHUR. He laughs as he picks at his teeth with a toothpick -- VERONICA rubs her reddened cheek. Tears in her eyes. But still defiant. She glares at FIONA.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Nice shot. But I’ve taken better.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What is this, exactly? The Theatre of the Absurd?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Oh you're very fond of your high- falutin’ phrases, aren’t you, Father. I do think you do look down on us country people. She knocks back her drink. Glancing out the window, she sees SIMON ASAMOAH approaching.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: There’s my ride, as it were. Let’s do this again some time. She exits. Leaving startled DINERS in her wake.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Do you have to put up with that kind of shit on a regular basis? Through the window we can see VERONICA as she reappears and throws her arms around ASAMOAH. ASAMOAH looks blankly at LAVELLE and FIONA.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: There’s a lot of it going around, let’s put it that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and FIONA walking along.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: We really should talk, you know. Get it all out.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Like in one of those shit plays at the Abbey?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t know what the third-act revelation would be, though.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Neither do I. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Tl. 74

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Your mother dying killed a little something in both of us, I know that.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It was a long goodbye if ever there was one. I sometimes wish she hadn't hung on as long as she did.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: She was stubborn, alright. But brave, too. I wonder if 1/11 be that brave, when it comes down to it.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t just her dying. You were missing in action a long time. Before and after. When I needed you the most.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Was it really that bad?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, maybe I’m exaggerating. You were a highly-functioning alcoholic, I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve always thought the “highly- functioning” part should cancel out the “alcoholic” part. Like a double negative. FIONA smiles. They come upon MICHEAL sitting in an old wooden boat, staring out to sea, a Davy Crockett hat on.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What are you up to, there, Micheal, if you don’t mind me asking?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Thinking.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Thinking. Thinking about what?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: Things.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Thinking about things. How profound.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: What’s that you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: A hat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: A hat. You don’t give much away, do you, Micheal? You should’ve been in the French Resistance, they could’ve done with men like you. FIONA laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE and FIONA manoeuvre between the rock-pools.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I was never neglectful, I don’t think. I never hit you or--

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: There are other forms of violence.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I know there are. Attempting suicide, for one.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Jesus. I walked into that one.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not only violence against yourself, either.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It wasn’t intended that way. I wasn’t trying to hurt you.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How could it not hurt me? I love you.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I love you, too. Don’t doubt that. They look at each other. Put their arms around each other and walk on.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: And just when I thought I had you back and you were all ship-shape and raring to go, go you did. I thought it’d be another woman.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I have a vocation. I wasn’t trying to escape or--

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I know that. I know you're sincere. But the fact remains, first she went away and then you went away. I lost two parents for the price of one. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I never went anywhere. I’m still here.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I think you’re being a little naive, there, Father. They stop as they reach the edge of the rock-face, lookin out over the sea.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’m still here. I’1l always be here.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Will you? (with a sad smile) You promise?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: (pointing to her heart) I'll always be here. (pointing to his heart) And you'll always be here. FIONA’s eyes well up with tears.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How's that for a third-act revelation?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: It's corny. But I like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN is lying fully-clothed on his bed, a multicoloured quilt beneath him. The shillelagh by his side. LAVELLE pours him a bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: You know how you can tell when you're really getting old?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Nobody says the word “death” around you anymore. LAVELLE looks at him. Holds out the glass. RYAN pops two large pills from a vial into his mouth. Takes the glass -

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Here's mud in your eye! Tosses back the bourbon in one go. Motions for another. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: That's great stuff! Makes me feel like bursting into song. LAVELLE takes the glass. Fixes him another.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Go on ahead for yourself. Nobody’s stopping you. RYAN raises the shillelagh as if it were a conductor’s baton and sings --

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: “You will eat, by and by, in that glorious land above the sky--” LAVELLE smiles. Shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: “--Work and pray, live on hay, you'll get pie in the sky when you die!”

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: God, you're an awful man altogether. RYAN cackles. LAVELLE hands him the bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Like the fella said, “There has to be a Devil before there can be holy water.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE walks through the fields behind the rectory, lighting his way with an old oil lamp.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Bruno! Bruno! He goes on through the fields. Pauses, having spotted something up ahead. Walks on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE's POV -- the dog lying dead. LAVELLE looks down at the dog. Its throat has been cut. A puddle of blood around its body. He crouches beside the body. Touches its coat.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah what has he done to you? (crying softly) What has he done to you, Bruno? He strokes the glossy coat, still crying.  15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE finishes digging a hole. Puts the shovel to one side, where Bruno lies enveloped in a bright red blanket. He hefts the bundle and places it gently in the hole. Shovels earth onto the bundle until it is completely covered. Pats it down. He puts his hands together atop the shovel and says a prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE -- “Friday”. The convertible screeches to a halt. FIONA jumping out with her suitcase. LAVELLE getting out --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I forgot to say goodbye to

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I'll give him a big kiss from you.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Oh do! They hug and kiss --

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: I'll be fine, you know.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Will you?

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Well let’s just say, today I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: So you say. She smiles, and disappears into the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE strolls along, brooding. He comes up alongside a young GIRL on her own. Picking petals off a flower.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Hello. Where are you off to? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: The beach.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s nice at the beach, isn’t it. Do you surf?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: No, my Da won't let me. He says it’s too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Ah, what does he know. Big meanie. The GIRL laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Here on holiday? She nods.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Where are you from, Wicklow?

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Well never mind. We won’t hold it against you-- Suddenly, a car screeches to a halt on the main road in front of them. A MAN gets out, angry --

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Janine! Get in the car, now. The GIRL quickly crosses to the car.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (softly) Where the hell d’ya get to, honey? I’ve been looking all over for ya. The GIRL gets in. The MAN turns to LAVELLE, angry again -

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What were you saying to her?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I wasn’t saying anything to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Oh really. You looked deep in fucking conversation to me. He glares at LAVELLE. Gets back in the car. Drives off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE stands there. Runs a hand through his hair. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - DAY 81

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Large one. LYNCH looks at him, as he clicks onto Sky News. He has a bandage on his hand. HARTE, seated at the end of the bar with a whiskey, glances at him also. ASAMOAH and BRENNAN are playing chess in a corner of the bar. BRENNAN looks round.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: You sure about that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Whiskey, I said. LYNCH gets the drink. Sky News playing a report from Afghanistan.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: I wonder what’s the latest in the sand-nigger war? ASAMOAH looks up. Smirks.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: Looks like more dead to me. But then again, who’s counting? LYNCH passes LAVELLE the whiskey. LAVELLE knocks it back.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Have one yourself. Might shut you up.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Ah sure that’s what they call them, sand-niggers. The Marines, I mean. I read it in a book about that young one they raped and murdered, y’know? They killed her entire family, then they turned on her.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: That’s your bedside reading, is it?

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: I like to keep up with American foreign policy. Another? LAVELLE gives a slight nod. LYNCH turns to HARTE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Yourself?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: One ice cube this time. Two just get in the way. LYNCH gets the whiskies. ASAMOAH makes a chess move. BRENNAN smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: Who burned down your church, Father?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s not my church. It’s our church.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I’d say it was the Romanians. They’re heathens, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: The Romanians? What Romanians do we have around here?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Ah they’re always hanging around, the Romanians. Getting up to no good.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: I think it must be someone who does not like you, Father. I think it must be one of the good people in this town.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: You should join the Guards, Simon, with your powers of deduction.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Checkmate. ASAMOAH looks down at the pieces. Then back up at BRENNAN BRENNAN picks up his whiskey, and goes to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: These measures, hey, Father. It’s like a buttercup in the mouth of a cow. Guinness, there, Brendan. He knocks back his whiskey. Glances slyly at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: So you think there’s a God, then, Father, yeah? LAVELLE looks blankly at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I’m not codding, I’m being serious. I'm having doubts, like. A crisis of faith. LAVELLE looks blankly at him. Takes his drink and gets up

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Ah now, I didn’t mean to offend ya, I’m sorry. Really I am. As sure as there’s a hole in a goat. LYNCH laughs as he pours the Guinness. LAVELLE heads for the pool room.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I'm an awful messer, Father, God forgive me! Don’t go away mad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE on a rack of pool balls being split. LEO MACARTHUR, practising on his own, chalks his cue as h considers his next shot. Looks up -- LAVELLE is leaning against a wall, whiskey in hand.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: Hey Fada! Whaddaya hear, whaddaya say!

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You're back, so?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: I got a lotta clients in this town, Fada. From the hoi polloi to the masses of society. I gotta keep my ass lubricated at all times.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: The hoi polloi are the masses of society. You're using the phrase incorrectly. LEO pauses in the act of making a shot. Smirks.

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: That may be so, Fada. I didn’t get no education, see. I was getting fucked in the ass and fucked in the face all the live-long day. There wasn’t no time for any 0’ dat dere book-learnin’. I was sucking the prick of a bishop in his bishopric on a regular basis, ya get me? How d’ya like that play on words, smartass? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Do you need help?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: You're starting to sound a little screwy, now, Fada. Maybe ya need to see a headshrinker yerself--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Do you need help? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LEO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing wrong with me, my friend, I’m feelin’ fine. He smacks in a ball. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - NIGHT 83 LAVELLE at a table, brooding over a Guinness with a whiskey chaser. HARTE mooches over.

dialogues.speaker: HARTE
dialogues.text: y'know when I first started working in Dublin, there was this three- year-old boy whose parents had taken him into the hospital for a routine operation, but the anesthesiologist made a mistake, and the little boy ended up being deaf, dumb, blind and paralysed. For good. (pause) Think of it. Think of when that boy first regained consciousness. In the dark. You'd be frightened, wouldn’t you. But you'd be frightened in that way where you know that the fear is going to end. It has to. It must. Your parents can’t be too far away. They’1l come to your rescue. They’11 turn on the light and they'll talk to you. (pause) But think of it. Nobody comes to rescue you. No light is turned on. You are in the dark. You try to speak but you can’t. You try to move but you can’t. You try to cry out but you are unable to hear your own Screams. You are entombed within your own body, howling with terror. (pause) Your parents stand around you. They have no way to communicate with you. They have no way to explain what has happened to you. Will you ever understand what has happened to you? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HARTE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And that it will not end, that it will always be this way? There is silence for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What the fuck? Why the fuck would you tell me a story like that?

dialogues.speaker: HARTE,
dialogues.text: No reason. LAVELLE rears up -- HARTE goes into a karate stance -- ASAMOAH and LYNCH look round -- HARTE steps back quickly and scoots off. INT. LYNCH’S BAR - LATER 84 HOLD on LAVELLE as we JUMP-CUT through his night’s drinking, encompassing pints and shorts. Only ASAMOAH left in the bar with LYNCH. They pass a spliff back and forth, glancing at LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Time to go. Come on. LAVELLE looks round at ASAMOAH.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: He’s still drinking. Same again.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Time to go, I said.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What’s that, an order?

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: You do not like taking orders, Father? You do not mind giving them.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Sure his kind are all alike.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: My “kind”. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Yeah your “kind”. Your time has gone, and you don’t even fucking realise it.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: My time will never be gone.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: You hear that? The arrogance of the man.

dialogues.speaker: ASAMOAH
dialogues.text: You need to be a little more humble, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: He needs taking down a peg or two, is what he needs. LAVELLE looks at them both. He steps down from his stool, puts his hand into the pocket of his soutane, and withdraws the Webley revolver, aiming it at them -—

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Take me down, then. ASAMOAH steps back, but LYNCH doesn’t flinch. He looks coolly at LAVELLE --

dialogues.speaker: LYNCH
dialogues.text: Go on. I fucking dare ya. LAVELLE looks blankly at him. Adjusts his aim and fires - Into the ranks of spirits and the mirror behind the bar, shattering nearly everything -- EXT. LYNCH’S BAR - NIGHT 85 The blasts from the revolver lighting up the bar -- INT. LYNCH’S BAR - NIGHT 86 The gun clicks. Empty. All six shots fired. LAVELLE looks at LYNCH and ASAMOAH, swaying slightly. LYNCH reaches under the bar and produces a yellow basebal bat. ASAMOAH grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE washing his bloody hands in the sink. His bloody face reflected in the mirror. LEARY, in pyjamas, passes by the open doorway -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! What happened to you? *

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Brendan Lynch.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Brendan Lynch? Sure he’s a Buddhist.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: So what if he’s a fucking Buddhist? You think Buddhists don’t beat people up? You think Buddhists don’t fuck their kids just like everybody else?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: You're obviously very upset--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Tibetans spit on blind people in the street. They're killing albinos in Africa. You are so fucking naive.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Please don’t curse at me, Father. And I think it’d be best if we continue this conversation in the morning when you’re sober--

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why are you a fucking priest at all? You should be a fucking accountant in a fucking insurance firm! He slams shut the door. INT. LAVELLE’S ROOM - MORNING 88 TITLE -- “Saturday”. LAVELLE lying prone on his bed, bruises all over his body still wearing his trousers and socks. His soutane in a black pile on the floor. He awakens. Gives a wretched groan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEARY hands a suitcase to a CABBIE -- *

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're leaving. LEARY turns. LAVELLE is standing there, squinting in the sunlight. Wearing a horrible woollen V-neck sweater. Drinking from a pint-glass of water. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: I think it’s for the best.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Because of last night?

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Because of a lot of things. Not just last night, or what’s happened here. I’ve been having doubts...about my sexuality, if you must know.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You’re not gay, Father. You're not interesting enough to be gay. LEARY is taken aback yet again.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m sorry about what I said last night.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: You said what you said with such venom. I didn’t realise you hated me that much.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I don’t hate you at all.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Then why...

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s just that you have no integrity. And that’s the worst thing I can say about anybody.

dialogues.speaker: LEARY
dialogues.text: Well that’s...That’s just... He heads for the car.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I hope you find what you’re looking for. Good luck. LEARY gets into the cab. It drives away.  90 91 92 93 94 85.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH-ANGLE SHOT -- LAVELLE appears and stands amid the ruins of the church. Finds a blackened and burnt hymnal. Flicks through it. Tosses it aside. INT. LAVELLE’S ROOM - DAY 91 LAVELLE in smart civilian clothes. He tosses the copy of Moby Dick into a packed suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives through the town. Past the fields. The castle. Then ~~ MILO HERLIHY zooms up alongside on his motorcycle. Looks across at him. At the suitcase on the passenger seat. LAVELLE looks back at him. HERLIHY accelerates, speeding on ahead, disappearing out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Aer Arann plane is on the runaway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE is looking out at the airplane, waiting for the announcement to board.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Father. LAVELLE turns to find TERESA ROBERT standing next to him. She glances at his clothes, his cut lip.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Oh hello.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: You are going to Dublin?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes. (pause) Just getting away for a while, y'know.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: I heard about your church. A terrible thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: You must be very upset.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes I am. LAVELLE glances out the window —~ LAVELLE’s POV -- a coffin is being escorted to the plane by TWO BAGGAGE HANDLERS. LAVELLE turns back to TERESA. She is watching the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: I am bringing him home to his family in Italy. Dublin and then Rome.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How have you been?

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: People here have been very kind.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I mean...

dialogues.speaker: TERESA
dialogues.text: Some times I think I cannot go on. (turning to look at him) But I will go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSENGERS climb the steps of the airplane, LAVELLE and TERESA among them. LAVELLE pauses at the top, waiting his turn to enter the plane. He looks down -- LAVELLE’s POV -- the coffin has not yet been loaded. The TWO BAGGAGE HANDLERS are leaning against it. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Aer Arann plane traverses the sky. EXT. EASKEY -- NIGHT 96a LAVELLE in his sports car, speeding back to Easkey. INT. RECTORY (LAVELLE’S ROOM) - DAWN 97 TITLE -- “Sunday”. A light breeze is blowing through the open window and gently lifting the lace curtains. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE is lying in bed, idly watching the curtains. His soutane is hanging on the wall. INT. LAVELLE’S ROOM - DAWN 98 He buttons up the soutane. Fixes his collar. Kneels in front of the crucifix and says a prayer. Blesses himself. EXT. DOG’S-HOLE - MORNING 99 CLOSE on the Webley Revolver. LAVELLE weighs it in his hand. Then tosses it out into th crashing waves. A wide crack in the cliff-face, the sea rushing in and smashing upon the rocks. The spume shooting up to where LAVELLE is standing, his soutane fluttering in the wind, an almost mythic figure looking out over the Atlantic. FITZGERALD appears and approaches, unheard. Eventually LAVELLE turns, flinching at FITZGERALD’s proximity.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Thinking of throwing yourself in? They say it’s the easy way out.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Nothing easy about it, I wouldn't have thought. They look out at the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I'm in a bad way, Father. LAVELLE looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I’m not putting you on. I’ve been in a bad way for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to a psychia--

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Ah they just load you up on pills. Ask you about your feelings for your mother. Same auld shite since the ‘20s.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: How does this...this feeling down... How does it manifest itself? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Not wanting to do anything. Finding nothing worthwhile. A sense of... disassociation. Detachment.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: You have a lot to be thankful for, objectively.

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: I had a wife and kids and they meant nothing to me. I have money and it means nothing to me. I have life and it means nothing to me.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Where do you think this sense of detachment comes from?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: From nowhere. (pause) From nowhere. LAVELLE studies FITZGERALD as FITZGERALD looks out to sea He is obviously sincere, and in a lot of pain.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I have to meet someone now, but I/11 call up to the house after. We'll talk. Get you back on track. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: FITZGERALD
dialogues.text: Thank you, Father. Thank you. LAVELLE puts an arm around his shoulders. FITZGERALD lean into him, resting his head in the crook of LAVELLE’s neck

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA on her cellphone. Coffee beside her. Dublin skyline

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: y'know, you changed the subject, the other day when we were talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE on the payphone.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: What was the subject?

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. EASKEY
dialogues.text: As they speak, we see images of the locations where they spent time together, these locations now deserted -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Train station. Lynch’s bar. Lavelle’s room. Country road. Easkey River. Split-rock. Confessional. Church ruins. Rectory exterior. Restaurant. Beach. Shoreline.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You know what the subject was. I think you committed a sin of omission there, if truth be told.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Sure there are worse sins than sins of omission.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well now you'd be the expert in that department, Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You'll have to defer to me, so.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I suppose I will.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think there’s too much talk about sins, to be honest, and not enough talk about virtues.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: You might be right. What would be your number one?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I think forgiveness has been highly underrated.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (after a pause) I forgive you. Do you forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SLOW-MOTION TRACKING SHOT following LAVELLE as he walks through the town. It is still early. He sees no one. Suddenly, GERALD RYAN appears in front of him --

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Father.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Little early for Mass. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Doctor Harte was out fishing at the crack of dawn. He begrudgingly gave me a ride. He’s a wonderful doctor, but a completely appalling human being. Where are you headed?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Just down to the beach there.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Want some company?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Not really, no. Maybe later.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: Fair enough. I won't keep you. He starts to move off, leaning on his shillelagh.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Did you finish your book?

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: I did. Not sure how good it is...

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’m sure it’1l be grand. You're a fine writer.

dialogues.speaker: RYAN
dialogues.text: (moved) Thank you, James. LAVELLE nods and walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE comes down onto the beach. Looks around -- LAVELLE’s POV -- there is no one to be seen on the beach. But far off, some SURFERS are riding the waves. He strides out, a lone figure out for a Sunday stroll. Th surf rolling in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHEAL is painting with oils. A canvas set up on an easel. He pauses -- MICHEAL’s POV -- LAVELLE looking out to sea. And then a second MAN, approaching from the right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE turns and sees the MAN approaching -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: LAVELLE’s POV -- the MAN gradually defines himself as JAC BRENNAN. Wearing a plain white shirt, the cuffs turned up ordinary black trousers, black shoes. As BRENNAN nears LAVELLE, he takes a gun from a trouser pocket and holds it loosely at his side.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Take your hands out of your pockets. Slowly.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I heard you had a gun. LAVELLE slowly removes his hands from the pockets of his soutane and turns them palms up.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Have to say I’m surprised. Thought I’d have to go looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Just because I’m here, doesn’t mean you have to go through with it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Yes it does. It’s one of those... self-fulfilling prophecies. Did you really think it’d come to this, though, hah?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I was hoping it wouldn’t. I thought you were a friend of mine.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Ah sure, a friend is just an enemy you haven't made yet.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Cheap cynicism.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: No, not cheap, now. That’s a cynicism that was hard-won. That's a cynicism that was earned after a hell of a lot of psychological and physical torture.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I take it back, then. But it’s cynicism all the same. That’s the difference between us, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: That’s not the only difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRENNAN looks out over the waves. LAVELLE appraising him. They look

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Any regrets?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I never got to finish Moby Dick.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: The whale kills Ahab.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Then he destroys the rest of the ship and the crew along with it. All except for Ishmael. He alone escapes to tell thee. at each other for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: The burning of the church I under- stand. But you didn’t have to kill my dog.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I didn’t kill your dog. Why would I do a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I found him. Out in the field. His throat had been cut.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Nothing to do with me. I am wholly innocent of that crime. (pause) I did give veronica a shove that one time, though. I admit that and I’m sorry for it. (pause) Did it upset you? The dog?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes it did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Did you cry?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: That’s nice. And when you read about what your fellow priests did to all those poor children down all those years, did you cry then? LAVELLE looks blankly at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: I asked you a question. Did you cry then?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No, I suppose-—

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I suppose I felt detached from it. The way you are when you read any- thing in a newspaper or see it on televis-- BRENNAN raises the gun and fires -- LAVELLE is hit in the lower left side and staggers back, collapsing onto the sand.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Detach yourself from that.

dialogues.speaker: DUNES
dialogues.text: MICHEAL sees BRENNAN fire the shot and LAVELLE go down. H takes a step back, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: 110  ull 112 113 94. EXT. BEACH - MORNING a LAVELLE touches his wound, his hand coming away bloody.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: We were the lucky ones, though. There are bodies buried back there. Buried like dogs. LAVELLE puts his hand over the wound once more, feeling the blood pulsing out. He looks around -- LAVELLE’s POV -- the beach. The SURFERS. BRENNAN. The sky BRENNAN approaches LAVELLE and aims the gun at his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHEAL drops his brush and runs down through the dunes -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAVELLE looks up at BRENNAN.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me. LAVELLE holds his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Don’t look at me. Turn your face to the side. LAVELLE holds his gaze. BRENNAN hesitates. Hears a sound and turns -- MICHEAL appears, running and tumbling down from the dunes and out onto the beach -- BRENNAN turns his aim on MICHEAL

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: No! MICHEAL pauses, looking from BRENNAN to LAVELLE --

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: Run, Micheal!

dialogues.speaker: MICHEAL
dialogues.text: I’11 get Stanton, Father! HELICOPTER SHOT -- MICHEAL retreats and runs towards the town. BRENNAN turns back to LAVELLE.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: He reminds me of me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He starts to sob. He moves off towards the surf, trying t regain his composure. LAVELLE watches him, his face turning pale as the life ebbs from him.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: It’s not too late, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: (still sobbing) Yes it is. Yes it is. He turns back, wiping his tears with his gun-hand. He takes a deep breath, then aims the gun at LAVELLE again.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNAN
dialogues.text: Say your prayers.

dialogues.speaker: LAVELLE
dialogues.text: I’ve already said them. BRENNAN fires, point-blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RYAN on a bench, eating an ice cream. INT. ASAMOAH’S HOUSE (BEDROOM) - MORNING 116 VERONICA astride ASAMOAH. He rubs the bruise on her face with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FITZGERALD sitting at a large oak table, dishevelled. A whiskey in front of him. He glances at his watch. INT. STANTON’S HOUSE - MORNING 118 STANTON looking through a magnifying glass, examining a bank note taken from a stack in front of him. He grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FREDDIE JOYCE being stomped on, the legs of OTHER PRISONERS kicking at him. He tries to protect himself, bu does not cry out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEARY in the “Philosophy & Religion” section, flicking through Richard Dawkins’ The God Delusion.  121 122 123 124 125 126 127 128 96.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FIONA walking with a HANDSOME MAN. Her hands in gloves. Laughing at something he has said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEO sitting naked at the edge of a bed. Thinking. A crucifix on a chain around his neck. A MAN’s form glimpse under the bedclothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MILO signing up. He passes the form back across to the RECRUITMENT OFFICER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOCTOR HARTE puffing on a cigarette, then putting it out on a diseased heart in a steel dish, the butt sticking up INT. LY¥NCH’S BAR - MORNING 125 LYNCH putting a glass to the optic of a lone intact whiskey bottle. His face bruised, his lip split.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TERESA ROBERT in business-class, looking out a window. Vodka-and-tonic in front of her. She blesses herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELICOPTER SHOT -- BRENNAN walks away from the body of LAVELLE. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE IN on a line of cubicles -. TRACK ALONG the VISITORS speaking with PRISONERS on telephones, separated by glass -- Coming to rest on FIONA. She is obviously devastated, but is sitting calmly, waiting. On the other side of the glass, a door opens -- JACK BRENNAN appears with the GUARD seen earlier. He look devastated also. He sees FIONA. FIONA looks blankly at him. Picks up her telephone. BRENNAN stands for a moment longer. Then hesitantly approaches the cubicle and sits down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: FIONA waits. Tears in her eyes. BRENNAN looks at her. Looks at the telephone. Looks back at her. CUT TO BLACK. The CLOSING TITLES play. Then the image of LAVELLE at the dog’s-hole appears, his back to us, his soutane flutterin in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pree a eke ea ee Rec uke nid
